properties.name: 23 skidoo
properties.description: Posted by Wept the librarywe wanted to hang out at the library. we scoured all of the music magazines looking for nine inch nails articles - i coughed as you ripped out the pictures. we read through the dictionary of slang. "23 skidoo" was when i knew i loved you. on the way home we found pictures in the gutter. you picked them up and we made a book with a glue stick and some paper, telling a fascinating story which these pictures further illustrated. your fan fell out of your window.

properties.name: A few guys tried to carjack me here
properties.description: Posted by Weptoff of mcdowell rd, scottsdale, azNote: this is not the exact location. I can\'t remember exactly where I was, but it was around there.. Anyway, I was driving to get a friend of mine when I realized that there was a bunch of what looked like saran wrap wrapped from one sign two another on opposite sides of the road. Since it was blocking the road, I had to stop.. At first I thought, what the hell? And then I looked in the mirror and saw a few guys running up behind my car towards me. I then realized that I was caught in the middle of quite a ridiculous and elaborate, yet incredibly unique car-jacking attempt. Luckily I was able to back up quickly and get the hell out of there before they got to me. But seriously, who would have thought of that idea? That\'s so crazy!

properties.name: A miracle happened here
properties.description: Posted by Wept4400 w thomas, phoenix, azAbout a week before I was going to move up to Portland I was pulled over by a cop here. The planning part of my move was not very strong: I had never been to Portland, I didn\'t have a job in Portland, I had barely enough money to get there, there were concerns as to whether or not my car would make it, etc. Anyhow, the point being that my plans were quite fragile. Also at the time I didn\'t have car insurance. The fine for this is quite hefty (in excess of ,000 I believe), and they can tow your car if they really want to be mean about it. When the cop pulled me over I thought my plans were done for, and I was pretty angry about it. The first thing that cops usually do when they pull you over of course is, "license/registration/proof of insurance." This cop said, "why did you run that red light?" me: "i didnt." her: "yes you did." me: "no i didnt." She then asked if I had been drinking, I said no. Then she told me to be safe on the road and left. She didn\'t even ask for my driver\'s license!

properties.name: Alki Beach
properties.description: Posted by Wept   seattle, waalki beach is a quasi-hidden secret great place. because its in west seattle, most people not in west seattle probably don\'t want to make the trip. it is really quite beautiful, and you have a great view from the beach to downtown from a certain angle, and another great view of some islands and boats and stuff from other angles. it is a bit hipstery and rich in some parts, but it\'s easily ignored. it has a nice bike and/or walking trail alongside the park, and there are some pretty okay restaurants and stuff along the way too. definitely a place to check out. parking can be a nightmare, though.

properties.name: Almost drove off a cliff here
properties.description: Posted by Weptnear california/or borderI think these are called the siskiyou mountains. I was driving up to Portland from Phoenix and once we hit these mountain ranges, it was unbelievably foggy. I couldn\'t see more than 2 to 3 feet in front of my car, if that. All I could hear were the noises of trucks surrounding me. I tried to follow the lines as best as I could see them in the road, but apparently I was following on the wrong side of the line. I saw that I was about to run into a road sign, stopped, and realized that just after the road sign was a very steep drop off. Thank god for road signs! After a while we were able to make it back onto the road and I followed inbetween two trucks that I was able to find via sound and then via their brake lights, and they guided us down through the mountains. It was very dark, very foggy, very scary, and I was very tired. I would recommend not going through this mountain pass 1) during the winter 2) at night, in winter or otherwise, or 3) when you are tired. Soon after you clear the mountains, you get around the Myrtle Beach area which is one of the most beautiful areas of Oregon in my opinion. It is a nice consolation prize.

properties.name: Audiovariancision, Atomic Cafe, circa 1997
properties.description: Posted by Wept   8005 E. Roosevelt, scottsdale, azAn amazing performance by Trent the Audio Architect of audiovariancision. This performance really had an incredible impact on my view of live performance as well as musical appreciation and creation in general. His music\'s incredible mix of electronic, industrial and tribal elements still amaze me to this day. I felt as if the one thing that was lacking from this show was a huge bon-fire in the middle of the place to dance around. And I don\'t mean that in a cheesy way at all. Simply amazing. The third best show I have ever seen in my life.

properties.name: Bicyclist tried to break into my car and kill me
properties.description: Posted by Wept  6th & spring, seattle, waI was at a red light, he rode his bike through traffic going the opposite way. He went through the red light toward me, hit my window on his way by, stopped his bike and proceeded to try to break my window and kick in my door. He was totally psycho. I called the cops, they said it happened all the time around there. They also said they probably wouldn\'t catch him. I saw him again that night about a mile away going through a crosswalk. I consider it a good sign that I didn\'t once have an urge to run him over.

properties.name: Bird and Exotic Clinic of Seattle
properties.description: Posted by WeptWhile it may be a bit difficult to find, this clinic is worth the effort. The staff is knowledgeable and very friendly. Dr. Dan is extremely good with rats, as is Dr. Kamaka. Dr. Dan is interested enough in rat care that he is persuing research (no, not that kind) to try to diagnose pituitary tumors in his rattie patients earlier than is now possible. That kind of dedication gives me great confidence. They specialize in exotic animals, especially birds and small mammals. While I have seen an occassional cat or dog, it\'s definitely not usual. Due to the birds, if you are bringing in a rat or small animal they may be subject to some squawking.

properties.name: Broken Fabiola, The Vogue, January 6th, 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1516 11th Avenue, Seattle, WA, 98122Broken Fabiola is a side project of the more angry project "Manufactura" by Karloz .M. I was very, very pleasantly surprised at how chill and great it was. The show was basically Karloz behind a sheet which had live video creations displayed on it. It was very low key, and the music was nuanced and great. The music was the kind of thing which takes you on a journey listening to it, and many times throughout the show I would find myself closing my eyes and letting it take me wherever it was going to. I even bought the album at the show, which is not very common for me. I shook his hand after the show and thanked him.

properties.name: Came within feet of a Presidential motorcade here
properties.description: Posted by Wept There were two protests scheduled when Bush was coming downtown for a fund raiser for Gordon Smith. One was marching from the south park blocks, the other was marching from Waterfront. We met at this point, and just as we were about to come together, the Presidential motorcade came through. It couldn\'t have been worse timing on their part. Inbetween an enormous protest and the President of the United States of America were only a few feet and a few Portland bicycle cops, who looked very scared and very angry. There were sharp shooters and helicopters flying overhead with people pointing guns at everyone all of the time, and that probably helped keep people in line as well. If you\'ve never seen a Presidential motorcade, I\'ll just say that it is truly a sight to behold.

properties.name: Car Flipped off I-17
properties.description: Posted by Wept4500 w thomas rd, phoenix, azI was trying to get onto the freeway when the car ahead of me on the onramp stopped. At first I didn\'t realize what had happened (it was night time), but I soon saw that there was a car upside down which I presume had flipped off of the I-17 freeway above us. It was mangled pretty badly and took me a while to really believe it was a car at all. Note: picture not actually the same overpass, although it does show some of the nice hideous faux-indian art of the area.

properties.name: Cleen, Paris Theatre, circa 2001
properties.description: Posted by Wept 6 Sw 3rd Avenue, Portland, OR, 97204This concert can only be described as a total and complete disappointment. The only shining light was the remake of "American Dreaming" originally by Dead Can Dance. After this concert I could barely even stand to listen to Cleen anymore. What the hell?

properties.name: Dead Can Dance, Paramount Theater, September 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept  911 Pine Street, Seattle, WA, 98101I seem to be in the minority here, but for the steep ticket price (0+) I expected more. They had a lot of the backing music on DAT or synth, the performance seemed a bit lackluster and without passion. Perhaps I was expecting something different than what they were expecting to deliver, but I was definitely not as impressed as I had expected to be. It was a good show, don\'t get me wrong. But for 0+, and for the probably 00-300k they raked in for that night, we as an audience deserved more.

properties.name: Downtown Seattle
properties.description: Posted by Wept   seattle, wadespite the fact that a crack addict tried to beat me up in my car one time downtown, i really love downtown seattle. it is what first attracted me to move here. i love skyscrapers, and even though its not exactly new york, its not disappointing either. the big curvy black building is especially nice to look at. the library downtown is unbelievable looking. "like something out of logan\'s run", a friend of mine said. the famed market downtown is fun for a while, but there are so many people there it\'s maddening after too long. there are lots of street vendors selling food and that kind of thing on the weekends. it has a very nice feeling overall, but i would definitely recommend being wary and trying to stay out of some parts.

properties.name: EasyStreet Records
properties.description: Posted by Wept4559 California Avenue Southwest, Seattle, WA 98116 a pretty good record store. it has a little too much of a hipster vibe but if you can get over that it is nice. they also serve breakfast for some reason (??). they have a whole section of used cds on the second level, so dont be deceived into buying new stuff if you dont have to! i think they also have a lot of live performances there, but ive never been to one. they recently had a "richard marx greatest hits" as a staff pick. i dont know about that.

properties.name: Erasure, Moore Theatre, July 24th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1932 2nd Ave., Seattle, WA, United StatesVery stressful trip up to Seattle to make it in time - had to cut out early of a tutorial at the Ubuntu Live conference to make it, and even then we cut it very short. Ended up timing it almost perfectly - the show started about 10 minutes after we arrived. When we first got in the venue I noticed it was about 20 degrees hotter in there than outside. Grrrreat! My wife had gotten me tickets to this sold-out show for my birthday. I was initially excited but, as always, ready for the show to be a complete flop (because so many are.) I was very pleasantly removed of that concern in short order. They played a few tracks from their new album (yes, they actually do have a new album - and it\'s actually good!), and they played a lot of their old hits. Chains of love, blue savannah, Drama!, almost every damn thing off of their "Pop 20 Hits" album (although not You Surround Me, which is my favorite - ah well). Despite the fact that they aren\'t exactly young anymore, they were still great showman and Andy Bell had more energy than most 20-somethings. The outfits he/they wore and the stage was just straight out of the 80s - it was hilarious. This show is definitely in my top 10 list of shows. After a while, I stopped caring that it was about 20000 degrees inside. Side note: after a very bad experience after a Skinny Puppy concert where I thought that I had permanent hearing damage, I am a real nazi about wearing earplugs at all concerts I attend. Surprisingly the music was mixed so well and the levels were so perfect, I rarely felt I needed to wear my earplugs - except, for when the songs were over. The crowd was so goddamn loud and insane (and the average age was around mid-30s, maybe even 40s! I think we were some of the youngest people there.) I have been to many-a-Morrissey show, who has a legendary cult following, but this crowd was about 10x more insanely in love with Andy Bell than the crowds I\'ve seen for Morrissey. Unbelievable, I know...but true! Side note 2: The photo below seems to actually be of the stage in Seattle, or at least very similar.

properties.name: Faithless, The Fillmore, April 30 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept1805 Geary Blvd, San Francisco, CADespite having the worst hotel room on earth and screwing up my knee from walking up and down San Francisco\'s hills before the concert, this concert was great. The venue was very nice, and we were able to be about 10 feet from the stage. Faithless sells out huge venues in Europe, and seeing them in this much smaller setting was something that I don\'t think very many people get to see. There were some people who actually flew from England to see them at this show and it seemed like they were about to die of excitement. One note: even though its pretty fun to be in the front during a concert, the sound is not very good in the very front for obvious reasons. I don\'t think I would want to be that close for a concert again. Crappy quality video clip from the show:

properties.name: Finally saw Skinny Puppy here.  Roseland
properties.description: Posted by Wept  8 Northwest 6th Avenue, Portland, OR, 97209After a failed attempt to travel to see them in Dresden, Germany for their reunion performance, I finally saw them a bit closer to home. Although they played a few newer songs which I don\'t exactly enjoy, it was incredible to finally see them in person. A band which has influenced me more than any other musically, personally, emotionally and a lot more... Seeing them live and in person was an unexplainable joy. Although I think the show would have been even better had I caught them in their prime (at least during the Last Rights era), it was still great. A checkbox checked off of my "list of things I have to do before I die." Oh, also, my ears rang for literally a week afterward. As a music fiend, it scared me more than anything ever has. I have worn ear plugs at every show I\'ve been to ever since.

properties.name: Food Cart For Sale
properties.description: Posted by Deisnor

properties.name: Fuller
properties.description: Posted by Wept136 Nw 9th Ave, Portland, ORtest

properties.name: Gay Denny's
properties.description: Posted by Wept 5002 N. 7th St., Phoenix, AZWhat can be said about Gay Dennys? It\'s ubiquitous. Say "Gay Dennys" to just about anyone 15-35 years old in Phoenix and they will probably know what place you are talking about. As far as Denny\'ses(?!) go, this one is a definitely a must-go. The last time I went there they had changed the layout to the more "50s diner" though. :(

properties.name: Green Lake
properties.description: Posted by Wept  7201 East Green Lake Dr N, Seattle, WAthe best park i\'ve found in seattle. it is exceptionally beautiful there (as long as you can filter out all the runners). especially good on really cold days or rainy days when the runners arent clogging it up. in the summer people swim here. a few open pipes leading into the lake itself have made me think this isnt a good idea. you can also rent little paddle boats during the more sunny months. you can see rabbits here (unfortunately abandoned pets), and also sometimes rats (some of them also obviously abandoned) if you look hard enough. nice park areas all around, too.

properties.name: Hallucinogen/Shpongle, The Fenix Underground, June 16, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept109 S Washington St, Seattle, WAThis concert was originally supposed to also feature younger brother, which would have been fucking awesome judging by the video at the bottom (not to mention the album they have released!) Unfortunately one of the guys from YB cancelled at the last minute, and so we got KoxBox instead, which was really quite terrible. Not only was he terrible, but he wouldn\'t get off the stage for Simon Posford. WTF? The hallucinogen set was good - I\'m not a huge hallucinogen fan but it was enjoyable anyway. The shpongle set was unfortunately a DJ only set, probably because the other half of Shpongle didn\'t want to venture over to this side of the ocean. All in all a very good show despite Koxbox and the lack of Younger Brother. A band I never thought I would see live. Posford has definitely done way too many drugs, but it seems like he is very happy about it anyway. Younger brother live at brixton: Actual clip from hallucinogen in seattle:

properties.name: Hawthorne Fish House
properties.description: Posted by Wept4343 Se Hawthorne Blvd, Portland, OR

properties.name: I was robbed here when I was like 12 years old
properties.description: Posted by WeptPhoenix, azA guy came up to me and told me to give him money. He wanted at least . I was in 7th grade! I was going to play video games at Castles and Coasters across the street. :(

properties.name: Intersection where a frat boy screamed lyrics at me
properties.description: Posted by WeptMy wife (fiancee at the time) and I were walking home from shopping at Fred Meyer nearby and this frat-like kid drives up and hangs almost his entire body out of his car window and yells right at us: "I AM THE GOD OF HELL FIRE! AND I BRING YOU FIRE!" about 3 times. At the time I didn\'t know this was well referenced, so thought that despite his fratness, he was a fan of Electric Hellfire Club. This greatly impressed, amazed, and kind of frightened me. We laughed for an incredibly long amount of time.

properties.name: Meat Beat Manifesto, Nuemos, June 10th, 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept 925 E Pike St, Seattle, WAThis place was incredibly loud, and not in a good way. Luckily by this time, I had had a very scary experience with hearing loss at the Skinny Puppy show and was wearing earplugs. The coolest part of this show was that they had a video screen that was playing all of the videos from which they got their samples, at the right time in the song. The bad part of the show was that it was BOOOORRRRIINNNGGG. They even seemed bored! My wife and I ended up leaving after about 4 songs. Shame, really... I have(had?) admired MBM for over a decade.

properties.name: Metro Cinemas
properties.description: Posted by Wept  4500 9th Avenue NE, seattle, wametro cinemas is a perfect mix of small and large theater. big enough to not feel like you\'re trapped in an airplane and small enough to not feel like you\'re sending money to the carlyle group with your ticket. its clean, the sound is good, the seats are nice, etc. the only complaint i have about this place is that because it\'s near the university, it seems to attract a rather annoying audience who sometimes like to talk through the whole damn movie. other than that, its nice, and its part of a network of "alternative"ish movie theaters.

properties.name: Ministry, Mesa Ampitheater, March 11, 19
properties.description: Posted by WeptMesa, AZYou know, given Ministry\'s hardcore appearance, I think this might be surprising. But, one word can sum up this show: BORING. Back to the drugs, Al! He also continually insulted the audience. Classy. The best part of this show was the after-show show at The Nile Theater in Mesa, AZ. N17 played which was great, but there was this other band whose name I don\'t remember. Their vocalist\'s main tactic was just screaming (and I really mean SCREAMING) unintelligible things into the microphone. As annoying as it might sound, it was actually very interesting and cool to me at the time. He got so into it he accidentally fell of the stage, and then just continued to yell into the microphone in the fetal position on the floor. Thumbs up for that guy! At least he wasn\'t boring! This crazy guy kept asking me, "how many decibles do you think that\'s putting out?!"

properties.name: Morrissey, Paramount Theatre, May 6th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept 911 Pine St., Seattle, WA, United StatesWhat can be said? Morrissey just keeps getting better and better. Unexpectedly fucking amazing rendition of "Life is a Pigsty" which made me wish yet again that my eyeballs had a record button. The encore of "Please, please, please let me get what I want" could make a grown man cry. I was actually expecting this concert to be not so great. Morrissey is getting older, his latest album wasn\'t that great, etc. But, I\'ve seen Morrissey 4 or 5 times now, and I have to say that this, as a whole, was probably the best show I\'ve ever seen from him. There are few musicians who can maintain the quality of their music and performance this long, luckily for me Morrissey is one of them! Life is a pigsty (in Zagreb):

properties.name: Piecora's Pizza
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1401 East Madison Street, Seattle, WApizza is actually surprisingly gross, however the bread, salads, and non-pizza italian food is really, really, really good. the atmosphere can be categorized as "loud as hell" due to the incessant playing of ac/dc and the like. however, the food is more often than not, worth it. parking is available in the back too, which is nice. the staff can be nice, or bitchty, depending on their mood.

properties.name: Powell's City of Books
properties.description: Posted by Wept1005 W Burnside; portland, or

properties.name: Prick, LOA, TKK at Party Gardens, July 5th, 1995
properties.description: Posted by Wept   5555 E Vanburen, phoenix, azLet me preface this by saying that the ONLY reason I wanted to go to this concert was to see Prick. Prick was the opening band. We were picking up a notoriously late girl on the way to the show. Before the show I said to everyone, "if she is not ready, we are leaving her ass there." "Okay." says everyone. Yeah right. She is, of course, not ready. It takes her literally AN HOUR to become ready. Then, we get in a goddamn accident on the freeway. Needless to say, when we arrived Prick was finishing their last song in their set. Then, I had to sit through Lords of Acid and Thrill Kill Kult. This was almost completely unbareable. Not only physically, due to it being the middle of the summer in Arizona with a place that was violating the law by not having free water available and me being too poor to have any money to buy any, but also because TKK and LOA are SO HORRIBLE. Lords of Acid is the biggest cliche on earth - their lead singer (female of course) was simulating sex with a blow up doll on stage. Of course, everyone was loving it (well, all the guys at least), and that\'s why she does it. But jesus, when did going to a music show turn into going into a strip club? This was a really miserable experience all around. I was so pissed off. Thinking about it still pisses me off. IM PISSED OFF RIGHT NOW IN FACT!

properties.name: Saw Presidential Motorcade here
properties.description: Posted by WeptI was driving east on the freeway and noticed that there were no cars on the other side of the freeway. Then I remembered that Bush was coming to town for something or other, and judging by the cops on all the overpasses, I figured this was why no one was on the freeway. I pulled off near the Gateway Transit Center to watch, as many people already were. This Presidential motorcade was a lot longer and more incredible than the one I had previously witnessed downtown. First, about 5 motorcycle cops cruised down the freeway way ahead of the motorcade, then probably about 7-10 normal cops, followed by about 3 suvs with guys hanging out of the back with guns, followed by 3 Presidential limousines (with two flags on either side of the front of the limousine), followed by pretty much the mirror image of what had just preceded them. In addition, there were a few ambulances trailing the entire thing. It was really pretty crazy. I can\'t imagine living in Washington, DC if this kind of thing has to interrupt traffic all the time. Must be nice to be the President and never have to worry about traffic (well, and all the other perks.)

properties.name: Sesame Donuts
properties.description: Posted by Wept6990 Sw Beaverton Hillsdale Hwy, Portland, ORtasty donuts, friendly staff, 24 hours!

properties.name: Sleeping with the Earth, Baltic Room, 2005
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1207 Pine Street, Seattle, WA, 98101At the entrance to this show, they gave out ear plugs. This should have been the first warning signal. In addition to the normal club speakers, they had erected an additional set of at least two more speakers. It was REALLY loud. I can\'t possibly explain how loud it was to do it justice. The opening DJs were so horrible that we stayed outside for most of it. When SWTE came on, the bass was so incredibly loud and strong that it literally made me physically sick from shaking my insides. It was like riding a really psychotic rollercoaster. Eventually I decided I could not physically stand it anymore, and we left. Unfortunate, because I really do like SWTE and I enjoyed the music - it was simply too loud. Perhaps, that makes me too old!

properties.name: Snog, Paris Theater, circa August 24th, 2001
properties.description: Posted by Wept 6 Sw 3rd Avenue, Portland, OR, 97204The opening bands for this show were so terrible I had to go outside. Snog wasn\'t all that great either, through no fault of their own. The sound at the Paris is notoriously terrible, and really all I heard was a horrible wall of sound. Too bad. I really like Snog.

properties.name: Someday Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Wept 125 NW 5th Avenue, Portland, OregonHere at a little show by former PLATIAL lead engineer, z0xx.

properties.name: Someday Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Wept 125 NW 5th Avenue, Portland, OregonHere at a little show by former PLATIAL lead engineer, z0xx.

properties.name: Southwest Animal Hospital
properties.description: Posted by Wept 6139 Sw Murray Blvd, Beaverton, OR, 97008Best rat vet I\'ve ever found. Dr. Burgess and Dr. Ramsell are both highly qualified and very nice. They specialize in exotic animals, but not birds, which means no loud squawking or barking to scare the buh-geezus out of your rattie.

properties.name: St. Francis 24 Hour Animal Hospital
properties.description: Posted by Wept St. Francis does not really specialize in rat care, but in an emergency it is a good place to go (after hours, it is much better for rats than Dove Lewis). Mr. Dr. Baker is an extremely nice and patient veterinarian. After the emergency is over, I would recommend transport over to Southwest Animal Hospital.

properties.name: Stripparaoke
properties.description: Posted by Wept5305 SE Foster Rd Portland, OR 97206test

properties.name: The Cure, America West Arena, August 18th, 1996
properties.description: Posted by Wept  400 West Washington Street, Phoenix, AZ, 85003This is, by far, the best concert I\'ve ever been to. The Cure had no opening bands, and they played for 3 hours straight. It was as perfect as could possibly be wished for. Their long version of "A Forest" was unbelievably amazing. It was one of those concerts where I could look around, and everyone in the place was as happy as they could possibly be. They played a LOT of their old material, as well. It was truly great. A not so great story that accompanies this concert is this one: To get tickets, I sat outside a mall for hours, starting the night before. There were about 5 people ahead of me. Because it was so damn hot outside, my friends and I took turns driving around the mall in the air conditioned car so that we wouldn\'t die. Anyhow, around the time the doors are about to open this hick pulls up, gives this guy that\'s been waiting in line some sum of money, and takes his place in line. Weird, I think. The doors finally open, we rush to the ticket counter, and this bastard isn\'t even buying tickets to The Cure, he\'s buying tickets for some goddamn country concert! AND, he\'s clearly a scalper. He is not just buying one, he is buying like 30, and he wants to hand-pick these seats. I was closer to murder that day than probably any moment in my entire life. Seriously. I was indescribably pissed off. Each seat that he picked to his crappy ass country concert was taking the time equivalent to a full row of Cure being wasted away. By the time I got to order my tickets, I still got floor seats, but very far in the back. Some people I knew who were waiting at another mall to get tickets that were similarly placed in line, but did not have said ticket scalper in front of them, got 2nd or 3rd row seats. I was so, very, very, very, very, very, very, very angry. It is something that can still get me extremely pissed off if I think about it for too long, and it was 10 years ago!

properties.name: The Metal Things
properties.description: Posted by Wept just off 19th and bell, phoenix, azThese are some great things to beat on with drum sticks, hammers or other things for your abnormal-percussion needs. Apparently someone wanted to build a business park here, and only got so far as to building an entrance, lining the place with some now-dead palm trees, and building some fountains (which are now dubbed "The Metal Things"). You can get an incredible variation of sound through these. There is a whole lot of metal in a lot of different configurations. The fountain is vertical so there are a lot of echoing possibilities. You can also get inside of them and bang away. There are metal and plastic pipes inside as well. Be sure to bring marching sticks! It is far enough from busy streets that no one knows what you\'re doing, and police seem to be surprisingly tolerant of this activity (I actually had an encounter with two Phoenix police officers while drumming away on the metal things and they said it was okay). All around, one of my favorite places in Phoenix...I had some great times here. I will be very sad when they develop this area and get rid of the fountains. It\'s been around for at least 10-15 years though, so who knows when that will be. -- Warning: stay out of the moat around the fountain. GROSS.

properties.name: Toad the Wet Sprocket, McMenamins Crystal Ballroom, August 13th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept1332 W Burnside St, Portland, ORThis band probably seems very odd to be placed among the others in this map, but ah well. TTWS is a band I\'ve loved since I was a kid, and since they broke up I thought I\'d never see them. About 5 days before this concert I saw on the Crystal Ballroom\'s marquee that they were playing and we got tickets - I didn\'t even know they had come back together to tour or anything, so it was a nice surprise. The concert was great - not anything mindblowing (they are just kind of a folk-rock band afterall), but really just....good. Some of their songs were ones that I played a lot during certain parts of my life, and it was nice to hear them played live. Not in my top 10 list or anything, but certainly a show I am very glad I went to. And yet another show where we were some of the youngest people in the audience. Woo! A clip of them playing "Windmills", one of my favorite songs, live (not at the show I went to, and not that great of quality, but "it\'s toad!")

properties.name: Tracey Smith
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingDorset, United Kingdom\'Slow Down and Green Up\'

properties.name: Tricky, Roseland Theater, August 3rd, 2001
properties.description: Posted by Wept  8 Northwest 6th Avenue, Portland, OR, 97209This was the second time I saw Tricky. The first was in or near Scottsdale, AZ and I have to admit that I wasn\'t that impressed. This time, however, it was a completely different experience. When Tricky was performing, it felt like his presence filled the entire room. When he performed "Tear Out My Eyes", it literally made my jaw drop. His band was also amazing, particularly the drummer. This show renewed my faith in Tricky and ultimately, upon reflection, led me to the ultimate belief that Tricky is simply a badass mother (shut yo mouth!).

properties.name: Tutta Bella Neapolitan Pizzeria
properties.description: Posted by Wept  4918 Rainier Avenue South, seattle, wa, 98118this is a pretty unique pizza place. they even have vegan pizzas. they make pizza in a "neapolitan" style which seems to mean a hell of a lot of sauce and not too much cheese. (there is actually a very strict definition of what this means - their website goes into detail about it) its pretty good! its the kind of pizza that doesnt make you feel sick after you eat it. the atmosphere was nice and all the employees were very nice as well, even during very busy times.

properties.name: Underworld at the Warfield, San Francisco 1999 - The best concert I've ever been to
properties.description: Posted by Wept san francisco, caI flew down from Portland to see this show, and I am so glad that I did. This is during the tour that resulted in the amazing "Everything, Everything" DVD/CD. The performers fed off of the energy of the audience, the audience fed off of the energy of the performers, and it was a wonderfully intense feedback loop. They played a version of "Rowla" that was beyond anything I\'ve ever experienced musically. This guy who was dressed in a suit, sweaty as hell from dancing, kept looking back at one of his friends and saying "I can\'t believe this!!". I couldn\'t have put it better.

properties.name: VNV Nation, Hawthorne Theater, June 29th, 2007
properties.description: Posted by Wept 1507 SE 39th St. Portland, OregonWell, unfortunately we made a horrible mistake in trying to skip the opening bands and showed up to find VNV playing their last song of the evening (before the encore). Ah well. I\'ve seen them twice before, and like Covenant, it\'s always a good show. The venue was ridiculous though - could the layout get any worse? There was a bar literally right in the middle of the floor. Who the hell thought that was a good idea? Let\'s ruin 1/4th of the viewing space! Awesome! VNV Nation\'s Kingdom live:

properties.name: Vain Salon
properties.description: Posted by Wepthipstery salon. a bit over the top with the hipsters, but if you can handle it, probably more fun than a supercuts.

properties.name: West Seattle Bowl
properties.description: Posted by Wept 4505 39th Ave SW, Seattle, WAbest bowling alley i\'ve ever been to. the employees are extremely nice, the place is extremely well taken care of. it is pretty much the only bowling alley where i dont feel disgusted or like i shouldnt touch anything lest i get a disease. they have some good specials during the weekdays (quartermania!), too.

properties.name: Where an old man threatened to beat me up with his tennis racquet
properties.description: Posted by Wept phoenix, azI was about 13 and was playing "street hockey" with my friends on a tennis court in this park. An old man came up and told us that we couldn\'t use the tennis courts because he wanted to play tennis, and threatened to beat me up with his tennis racquet. He was at the very least 65 years old.

properties.name: Where we got Jongy, George, Chuckie and Littleguy
properties.description: Posted by Wept portland, orWe got our 4 rats Jongy, George, Littleguy and Chuckie Noodle at Lloyd Center. Yes, I know it\'s a bad idea to buy pets from a pet store. However, we made the bad judgement call of going in to "just look" and came home the next day with Jongy after we couldn\'t stop thinking about him. About a month later we got his 3 brothers from the same place, since we figured they all probably shared the same diseases from the pet store. Ironically, they\'ve been the healthiest rats we\'ve owned, including rats from breeders. They are also extremely sweet and wonderful.

properties.name: almost drowned in the ocean
properties.description: Posted by Wept  san diego, cai was about 12 years old, and i didnt really think much about ocean swimming safety. i grew up in phoenix, so i knew how to swim fairly well, since everyone (well, except me) had a pool. oceans, i found, are very different than swimming in pools. my brother and i had gone out fairly far into the ocean, far beyond the point where we could still touch the ocean floor without having to go underwater. i realized that i was getting too tired to keep swimming, and attempted to swim back to shore. after a while, i realized i was making absolutely no progress. i was, in fact, even further away from the shore than when i started trying to swim back. i was caught in a riptide (although i didnt realize it at the time - i dont think i even knew what a riptide was exactly.) im not sure if this is how drowing in the ocean happens or not, but i went through a few phases of trying to keep afloat. the first was essentially just kicking my feet and staying afloat like normal, just like you would in a pool. after a while, that got extremely tiring, especially after i had just swam so much trying to get to shore. also around this time, i started getting hit by a lot of waves which was making breathing a lot more difficult. i embarked on a new plan: slowly letting myself drift down to the bottom of the ocean floor until i needed air, then swimming up to take a breath of air, keeping my head up as much as i could, trying to time it with wave crashing, and then slowly drifting down again - and repeat. during this last stage i became painfully aware that i was getting into a situation where i could easily drown. i remember being very scared, but also feeling like there was nothing i could do about it as i was completely out of energy. those two feelings kind of counteracted each other. i just kept bobbing. about the same time that i had pretty much resigned myself to the fact that i was going to die, i heard someone yelling. "you are caught in a riptide! swim diagonally! follow me!" a lifeguard had apparently seen me and apparently many others - although i had no idea anyone else was around.. they were mostly all on surfboards, it seemed like. i dont remember if i told him that i could no longer swim, or if he just knew, but he threw me that little orange thing they always carry around. i grabbed it and he started swimming for the shore. i could not believe how this guy could swim - i was making a huge wake as i was being dragged to the shore. when we arrived on shore i was about 3/4 to 1 mile away from where i originally started. the lifeguard asked me where i was from, and told me to be safe. i didnt know what to say - he had literally just saved my life. i said a simple \'thank you\'. it was the closest to death i think i\'ve ever been. i have a new respect for the "no lifeguard on duty" signs i used to laugh at. i haven\'t swam in the ocean since this incident.

properties.name: amazing drum beat from construction noises
properties.description: Posted by Weptdowntown portlandi was walking with my manager to our colocation place, and a nearby construction crew was using one of those things (i have no idea what it\'s called) that is basically a huge pole that goes up and down via air pressure to smash things into the ground, or to level ground. since it was pneumatic, it made an very loud SSHHHHHHHH sound every time the thing went up, and of course made a rather incredible sound when it hit whatever metal it was driving into the ground. this is a somewhat common sound downtown. however while we were walking, we came across this specific area where the timing of the construction noises and the echoes off of the buildings came together in perfect unison to create one of the most amazing drum beats ive ever heard. my manager at the time was talking to me about something or other and i just told him to stop talking and i stopped there and enjoyed it for the few brief moments that it lasted. it was incredible - i was speechless. my manager thought i was nuts.

properties.name: it felt like my favorite part of the saddest book ive ever read
properties.description: Posted by Weptphoenix, azwe hadn\'t talked in months. i sat in dead grass, rocks and dirt. it made me sick (everything did). you told me that you wished that i liked nature more. i hated the earth. you were disappointed in me again. i remember thinking you were more beautiful than anything in that city.

properties.name: my first tech job
properties.description: Posted by Wept4318 East Cactus Road, Phoenix, AZ, 85032the store wasn\'t completed when i was hired, and we had to help put it together. it was the middle of the summer, and the building didn\'t even have air conditioning yet. it was easily 100 degrees inside, probably more. we hung the shelves 5-10 minutes at a time and then rested. it was ridiculous. i got so hot that i threw up. it was originally a \'computer city\'. i took a \'pay cut\' from /hr at my data entry job to /hr here just to start doing something with computers. i did computer repair. it was horrible. the manager hated me for some unknown reason, even though he hired me. he got demoted later. this job was my entry into computer-related work, and thus a start of turning a love of technology into something that i can actually live off of, and an end to a larger aimlessness. still, it was compusa, and it was retail, and it was horrible. i loved and hated this job. memorable moments include: - getting electrocuted - getting electrocuted again - the salesman getting arrested for stealing cpus out of floor models and sticking them in his briefcase - kicking out many customers for being rude to me - the guy who sprayed \'endust for electronics\' onto his motherboard to clean it and somehow blamed compusa for it - the guy who was so angry that his monitor was dim that he slammed his laptop on the counter and yelled at me. i just walked away. later it turned out he had turned a dimmer switch down. ! - taking a customer into the back area to show her that nothing was wrong with her computer, plugging it in, and watching the power supply literally explode - being constantly mistaken for a target employee when i went next door due to the similarity of our uniforms - feigning illness to go see Tricky perform - figuring out how to trick their firewall into allowing me to irc - getting caught ircing

properties.name: portland, oregon.  the place that saved my life.
properties.description: Posted by Wept  portland, ori moved to portland in a hurry when i was 19 years old. coming from phoenix, az, i had finally decided that i couldn\'t take it there anymore. i previously thought that i would never move from phoenix. my family was there, my friends were there. where else would i go? one day, it just popped into my head that i had to leave. and fast. i demanded a raise at my job in phoenix - secretly to pay for my move. 2 months later i was in my car with my computer, some blankets, and some clothes. driving up to portland with no job, no place to stay, no real plan at all. i spent time in weekly hotels, some of worst motels you could imagine, and a horrible roach-infested apartment. i never once thought that i had made a mistake. i had never been to portland before, but it seemed like the complete opposite of phoenix from what i had heard about it. it rains, it has trees. these were the only two things i cared about. it seems funny to think back to that time, but its absolutely true. as we were driving toward portland, i was so anxious and so afraid that there weren\'t going to be enough trees. despite not having very much money, not having a job or a place to live, this was my primary concern: the number of trees. i remember being so scared about it. portland renewed my faith, in everything. i instantly felt good here. it will always be my home, no matter where i live. the land of portland, the people of portland - everything about it - i absolutely love. its beautiful.

properties.name: where i grew up
properties.description: Posted by Weptphoenix, azsuch a horrible place to grow up. my school had a mix of gangsters and kids who were bused in from the outlying desert areas (real cowboys). it was a pretty crazy mix of culture - unfortunately mostly fueled by hard-assed anger and ego. it led to an incredible number of fights. a few times i thought people were going to die. heads banging into concrete, resonating and echoing across the school. i almost threw up after seeing that one. teachers were sometimes hospitalized. my neighbor\'s house was hit by a drive-by. they sent one cop out. he stayed for less than 5 minutes. i traveled outside of this area fairly infrequently as a child - i thought everywhere was this terrible. strangely enough, i met some of the most wonderful people in my life in this city. they are few and far between - but they are there. everytime i come back, it is so different. the driving progress in this city is amazing, and disturbing. they drop a tostitos chip into some salsa on new years eve in one of the suburbs - tempe, az. a tostitos chip. in salsa.... christ. the only thing i miss is the monsoons, and the smell of the creosote right before it rains.
